case_name: Civil Appeal Nos. 1755 to 1756 of 1969, 362 to 363 and 1918 to 1920 of 1970 and 490 to 492 of 1973

facts.text: Civil Appeal Nos. 1755 to 1756 of 1969 were filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal Nos. 1755 to 1756 of 1969, 362 to 363 and 1918 to 1920 of 1970 and 490 to 492 of 1973.

facts.text: Appeals by special leave from Mysore High Court judgment dated 10th October 1968.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals by Special leave from the Judgment and Order dated the 10th October, 1968, 11th March, 1969, 24th March, 1969 and 16th June, 1969 of the Mysore High Court

facts.text: Mysore High Court delivered judgments in W.P. Nos. 3322 and 379/66.
There are twenty two appeals by special leave together with thirteen connected special leave petitions.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by BEG, J.-There are twenty two appeals by Special leave together with thirteen companynected special leave petitions involving a companymon question of law for decision before us.

facts.text: Anekal Scheme dated 15-4-1959 for nationalisation of transport services.

anchor.surface_text: This question arises out of three approved schemes, which may be called the Anekal Scheme dated 15-4-1959, the Gulbarga Scheme dated 18-2-1960, and the Bangalore Scheme dated 7-6-1960,

facts.text: Gulbarga Scheme dated 18-2-1960 for nationalisation under Chapter IVA of the Motor Vehicles Act, 1939.

anchor.surface_text: the Anekal Scheme dated 15-4-1959, the Gulbarga Scheme dated 18-2-1960, and the Bangalore Scheme dated 7-6-1960, for the nationalisation under Chapter IVA of th-- Motor Vehicles Act, 1939

facts.text: Bangalore Scheme dated 7-6-1960 for nationalisation of transport services on certain routes in State of Mysore.

anchor.surface_text: the Gulbarga Scheme dated 18-2-1960, and the Bangalore Scheme dated 7-6-1960, for the nationalisation under Chapter IVA of th-- Motor Vehicles Act, 1939  hereinafter referred to as the Act , of transport services on certain routes lying within the State of Mysore.

facts.text: Parts of intrastate routes under the schemes overlap inter-state routes over which private transporters were granted permits.

anchor.surface_text: But, parts of these intrastate routes overlap inter-state routes over which private transporters were granted permits and then their renewals by the State Transport authorities to ply their vehicles.

facts.text: Mysore State Road Transport Corporation objects to permits insofar as they cover overlapping portions of intrastate routes.

anchor.surface_text: The Mysore State Road Transport Corporation objects to these permits in so far as they companyer overlapping portions of intrastate routes.

facts.text: Regional Transport Officer granted or renewed permits to some inter-state operators.

anchor.surface_text: In some of the cases before us the Regional Transport Officer had himself either granted or renewed the permits of the inter-state operators.

facts.text: In other cases, Regional Transport Officer rejected applications but final state Appellate Authority granted permits to inter-state operators.

anchor.surface_text: In other cases, where the Regional Transport Officer had rejected the applications of the interstate operators companycerned, the operators had succeeded in obtaining permits from the final state Appellate Authority functioning under the Act.

facts.text: Mysore High Court upheld grants of permits to inter-state operators in every case.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court had, in every case, upheld the grants of permits to the inter-state operators.

facts.text: High Court found the schemes to be ambiguous.

anchor.surface_text: It had found the schemes to be ambiguous.

facts.text: Final Appellate Transport Authority imposed condition on each inter-state permit that operator will neither pick up nor drop passengers on overlapping notified route.

anchor.surface_text: It may be mentioned here that a companydition had been imposed by the final Appellate Transport Authority upon each inter- state operator that he will neither pick up number drop passengers on any part of the overlapping numberified route.

facts.text: Manager of appellant Corporation confined objection to sufficiency of buses on overlapping parts and did not rely on total prohibition.

anchor.surface_text: the Manager of the appellant Corporation had impliedly admitted before, the Transport authorities that interstate operators were number totally prohibited by any scheme from using overlapping portions because he companyfined his objection to the sufficiency of the number of buses serving on the overlapping parts of routes and had number relied upon any parts of the schemes for any alleged- total prohibition

facts.text: Rules notified in Mysore Gazette dated 27-2-1958 prescribe particulars for schemes.

anchor.surface_text: These particulars have been prescribed in the State of Mysore by means of rules numberified in the Mysore Gazette dated 27-2-1958.

facts.text: Anekal Scheme preamble does not state total exclusion.

anchor.surface_text: In the Anekal Scheme, the preamble does number state that the scheme is of total exclusion.

facts.text: Gulbarga scheme modified by deleting words 'or any portion thereof'.

anchor.surface_text: One of the modifications is-that the words or any portion thereof wherever they appear in companyumn 2 of the, statement appended to the scheme published by the General Manager shall be deleted.

facts.text: Bangalore scheme specifies complete exclusion for certain routes including services between any two places therein.

anchor.surface_text: the passenger transport services on the routes appearing at sl. Nos. 1 to 22 and 24, 25, 26, 27 anti 53 of the statement appended including services between any two places therein should be run and operated by the State Transport Undertaking to the companyplete exclusion of other operators

facts.text: Names of inter-state operators not mentioned in appended statements of schemes.

anchor.surface_text: Ile strongest point of the inter-state operators is that their names are number mentioned in the second appended statement.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismisses the appeals and special leave petitions.

anchor.surface_text: The result is that we do number see sufficient reason to interfere with the view taken by the High Court and dismiss these appeals and the special leave petitions.

facts.text: Schemes do not name inter-state operators or give numbers of their vehicles.

anchor.surface_text: If the exclusion of those using overlapping portions of the surface of the, highway companymon to two different routes was also really intended, they should have been named in the appended statement and the numbers of their stage carriages should have been given.

issues.text: Can a permit be granted to an Inter-State Transport Operator for the whole of his route despite the fact that a part of the route overlaps a part of a notified intra-State route?

anchor.surface_text: The common question of law which arises may be formulated as follows Can a permit be granted to an Inter-State Transport Operator for the whole of his route despite the fact that a part of the route overlaps a part of a notified intra-State route ? There can be no doubt that the Mysore State Transport Under-

issues.text: whether the Transport authorities had any power or jurisdiction to grant permits to interstate operators even by annexing such conditions so that overlapping portions of notified routes could be merely used by the inter-state operators concerned for taking their stage carriages and passengers through them but not to provide services for passengers to or from any place falling upon any portions of the notified routes.

anchor.surface_text: overlapping notified route. holdings.text: The Mysore State Transport Undertaking has the power under section 68C of Chapter IVA of the Motor Vehicles Act, 1939 to frame a scheme providing for exclusion, complete or partial, of other persons including inter-state motor operators altogether from a part of any notified route.

anchor.surface_text: There can be no doubt that the Mysore State Transport Under- taking has the power to frame a scheme under section 68C of Chapter IVA of the Act, providing in the public interest that road transport services in general or any particular class of such service in relation to area or route or portion thereof should be run and operated by the State Transport Undertaking, whether to the exclusion, complete or partial, of other persons or otherwise. This power includes the power to exclude even inter-state motor operators altogether from a part of any notified route.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of section 68C text and following precedents like Nilkanth Prasad, Standard Motor Union, Abdul Khader.

holdings.text: Approved schemes under Chapter IVA have the force of law and transport authorities have no power to deviate from or modify their terms; permits can only be issued in accordance with the schemes.

anchor.surface_text: The Transport authorities have no power to deviate from or modify the terms of approved schemes which have the force of law. They can issue or otherwise deal with permits only in accordance with the provisions of the schemes which may be either partial or total exclusion of private operators from notified routes.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory schemes bind authorities as they emerge after prescribed procedure under ss 68C-68D.

holdings.text: A 'route' under section 2(28A) of the Motor Vehicles Act is an abstract line of travel specifying the highway between two termini; different termini make different routes even with overlapping highway portions.

anchor.surface_text: A route, as defined by the insertion of 28A made by the Act 56 of 1969, in Section 2 of be Act, is a line of travel which specifies the high-way which may be traversed by a motor vehicle between one terminus and another. Whatever may have been the meaning of the word route before this insertion, it appears to us that, after this clarification, a route is not merely the physical surface covered by the high-way to be traversed, but the abstract concept of a line of travel, which connects one terminus with another, has also been introduced into the legal definition of a route.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory interpretation of amended definition emphasizing termini as essential.

holdings.text: Unless a nationalisation scheme clearly and unequivocally indicates prohibition of user of every portion of a notified intrastate route by inter-state operators (with different termini), mere physical overlapping does not exclude their passage without providing service on the overlapping portion.

anchor.surface_text: Unless a scheme clearly indicates that the user of every portion of a highway covered by an intrastate notified route is prohibited also to an inter-state motor vehicle operator, who really plies on a different route inasmuch as its termini are bound to be different from those of an intrastate route, the inter-state operator may not be completely debarred from the user of the overlapping part of an intrastate route. A mere physical overlapping of the two may not be enough to exclude the private interstate operators by any necessary implication.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Purposive and textual interpretation requiring clear intent for total user exclusion given route definition and public highway rights; omission of names in schemes supports.

holdings.text: The schemes in question (Anekal, Gulbarga, Bangalore) do not indicate total exclusion of inter-state operators from mere user of overlapping portions of notified routes.

anchor.surface_text: In the Anekal Scheme, the preamble does not state that the scheme is of total exclusion... the interpretation of the three schemes advanced on behalf of the inter-state operators is more reasonable.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Examination of preambles, clauses 3-7, appended statements omitting inter-state operators' names/vehicles; modifications deleting 'portion thereof'; non-reliance on total prohibition by Corporation manager.

holdings.text: Transport authorities have jurisdiction to grant inter-state permits covering overlapping notified intrastate routes subject to conditions prohibiting pick up or drop of passengers on overlapping portions.

anchor.surface_text: It may be mentioned here that a condition had been imposed by the final Appellate Transport Authority upon each inter- state operator that he will neither pick up nor drop passengers on any part of the overlapping notified route... We think that conditions were rightly imposed by the final Transport Appellate Authority on the permits of interstate operators to bring out what it understood the scheme to mean in each case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Conditions align with partial exclusion schemes allowing passage but not service; authorities enforce schemes without modification.

holdings.text: The schemes do not warrant total exclusion of inter-state operators from overlapping portions based on their language and contents.

anchor.surface_text: the real question to be considered is whether the scheme itself in each case, on the contents of it and the language employed by the framers of it, warrants total exclusion of the kind contended for before us on behalf of the Corporation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct textual analysis; ambiguity resolved against total exclusion due to omissions and scheme structure.

holdings.text: Nilkanth Prasad case is not applicable post-insertion of section 2(28A) defining 'route'.

anchor.surface_text: Nilkanth Prasad's case supra was decided before the insertion of the definition in Section 2(28A) of the Act before us... we do not think that the ratio decidendi of that case is applicable here.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Precedent distinguished due to subsequent statutory amendment clarifying 'route'.

holdings.text: The appeals and special leave petitions are dismissed; no interference with High Court view upholding permits.

anchor.surface_text: The result is that we do not see sufficient reason to interfere with the view taken by the High Court and dismiss these appeals and the special leave petitions.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of above holdings to facts; schemes interpreted as partial exclusion permitting conditional inter-state permits.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeals by special leave and special leave petitions dismissed; no interference with the High Court judgment upholding grants/renewals of permits to inter-state operators over overlapping portions of nationalised intra-state routes.

anchor.surface_text: There can be no doubt that the Mysore State Transport Under- taking has the power to frame a scheme under section 68C of Chapter IVA of the Act, providing in the public interest that road transport services in general or any particular class of such service in relation to area or route or portion thereof should be run and operated by the State Transport Undertaking, whether to the exclusion, complete or partial, of other persons or otherwise. This power includes the power to exclude even inter-state motor operators altogether from a part of any notified route.

anchor.surface_text: 9, in Section 2 of be Act, is a line of travel which specifies the high-way which may be traversed by a motor vehicle between one terminus and another

edges.explanation: Definition of 'route' as abstract line between termini distinguishes overlapping inter-state routes, addressing permit issue

anchor.surface_text: A route, as defined by the insertion of 28A made by the Act 56 of 1969, in Section 2 of be Act, is a line of travel which specifies the high-way which may be traversed by a motor vehicle between one terminus and another. Whatever may have been the meaning of the word route before this insertion, it appears to us that, after this clarification, a route is not merely the physical surface covered by the high-way to be traversed, but the abstract concept of a line of travel, which connects one terminus with another, has also been introduced into the legal definition of a route.
The result is that we do number see sufficient reason to interfere with the view taken by the High Court and dismiss these appeals and the special leave petitions.

A mere physical overlapping of the two may not be enough to exclude the private interstate operators by any necessary implication.
